description: From Latin ēlūdō (“evade, elude”), from ē (“out of”), short form of ex, + lūdō (“play; trick”).

verbs.description: elude (third-person singular simple present eludes, present participle eluding, simple past and past participle eluded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To evade or escape from (someone or something), especially by using cunning or skill.
examples: Thus the observation of human blindness and weakness is the result of all philosophy, and meets us at every turn, in spite of our endeavours to elude or avoid it.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shake off (a pursuer); to give someone the slip.
(transitive) To escape being understandable to; to be incomprehensible to.
examples: I get algebra, but calculus eludes me.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To escape someone's memory, to slip someone's mind.
examples: The solution of that brainteaser eludes me and the name of the author eludes my memory too.
